entry.et: Middle English, from Old English clǣg; akin to Old High German klīwa bran, Latin gluten glue, Middle Greek glia

def.dt: :an earthy material that is plastic when moist but hard when fired, that is composed mainly of fine particles of hydrous aluminum silicates and other minerals, and that is used for brick, tile, and pottery
:soil composed chiefly of this material having particles less than a specified size
:a substance that resembles clay in plasticity and is used for modeling
:the human body as distinguished from the spirit
:fundamental nature or character the common clay
Lucius Du Bi*gnon bixcla18.wavdu̇-ˈbin-yən 1897–1978 Am. gen.
:a tennis court with a clay surface or a synthetic surface that resembles clay
:a loam containing from 20 to 30 percent clay
:any of a group of hydrous silicates of aluminum and sometimes other metals formed chiefly in weathering processes and occurring especially in clay and shale
:a saucer-shaped target usually made of baked clay or limestone and pitch and thrown from a trap in skeet and trapshooting

entry.et: from the feet of the idol in Dan 2:33

def.dt: :a character flaw that is usually not readily apparent
